awd_titl_txt: Evolution and Adaptation: Ambiguity Attitudes with Optimal Risk Preferences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research in economic theory. The project seeks to advance how economists study individuals who must make decisions when the environment and possible outcomes are uncertain. People often appear to avoid these kinds of situations, preferring to safe and well-understood options over choices that seem risky, uncertain, or ambiguous in their benefits. Understanding how risk and ambiguity affect choices is important not only for predicting a host of individual decisions, such as saving, investment, education, and job selection. This kind of economic theory is also important assessing the impact of different policies, technological changes, or other economic factors on the economy. Not surprisingly, ambiguity aversion and pessimistic attitudes towards risk have played an ever-increasing role in applications to macroeconomics and finance. The research effort will address a gap in our current economic theory. It will provide a better model of how individuals make use of new information about risky and ambiguous situations. The model will also help us understand how attitudes towards risk and ambiguity compare across individuals. Finally, the new theory may offer sharper predictions. The team will use an approach based on evolution and adaptation to build this new theory. The project could develop new tools for use by business managers and policymakers, who often must form accurate predictions of how customers, employees, citizens, and other individuals will behave in risky situations. 

While there is now an abundance of research providing decision-theoretic foundations to models of ambiguity and risk aversion, much less is known about how evolution might select between competing models and approaches. This project will advance basic theory regarding risk and ambiguity by providing an evolutionary foundation for a new model, the adaptive model, that imposes significant structure on ambiguity and risk aversion. Important features will be that preferences should be dynamically consistent, even at the cost of consequentialism, and that different ambiguity preferences go hand in hand with departures from expected utility theory in the context of risk. Depending on how effectively individuals of a genotype can adapt the expression of their phenotype, the adaptive model can nest variants of several prominent models in the literature as special cases. This will permit the evaluation of these models based on a new set of primitive assumptions and will extend the general insights about the structure of preferences under uncertainty and their updating to applications of those models in the contexts of finance, macro and policy choice. The project will also help strengthen the interdisciplinary bridge between the fields of decision theory and evolutionary biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has resulted in a large set of results, which have been circulated within the field as a research paper and submitted for publication. The outcomes of this project have led to both conceptual and technical innovations.
The conceptual and general interest results of the project invoke an explicitly evolutionary focus and explain how evolutionary optimality gives rise to a particular class of preferences, which we refer to as adaptive preferences. The model helps address a number of open questions in the literature on choice under ambiguity and risk. First, the paper shows how evolutionary pressure implies that any pattern of ambiguity-averse behavior outside of a very narrow class necessitates violations of expected utility in the context of risk. Second, the paper justifies dynamically consistent updating of preferences in response to new information, even if it comes at the expense of other appealing properties such as consequentialism. Third, it demonstrates that it may be strictly optimal evolutionarily for individuals to randomize in their own choice as a means to hedge against ambiguity, even when they have access to exogenous sources of randomization. We discuss the relevance of these insights for applied models and also for the design of laboratory experiments in the context of ambiguity and information.
The technical innovations resulting from the project take our model of adaptive preferences as a starting point and provide a set of powerful duality results that link adaptive preferences to variants of well-known models of choice under ambiguity and risk. These results, thereby, provide a novel way to organize and select between the many behaviorally founded models in the literature. In particular, they show that for certain classes of adaptation strategies that are available to the individual, the choice behavior generated by our model is equivalent to that of specific variants of familiar models from the decision theory literature that ignore adaptation.
The results of this project have been circulated within the field packaged as a single research paper. However, given the large set of results we have obtained, the output of the project is now being divided into two separate papers for submission and publication. The first paper will be more conceptual and will focus on our first set of results; it will be aimed at a general audience. The second paper will be more technical and will focus on our second set of results; it will be aimed at a more specialized theory audience. The latter aspects of the project have already been invited for resubmission to a journal and the former will be submitted to a general interest journal in the near future.
